October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

Empowering women to become tomorrow’s leaders by building skills in board governance, networking, and community-driven decision making for lasting impact.Through this comprehensive training, participants will learn how to navigate the responsibilities of being a nonprofit board member. We focus on practical, hands-on skills including team building, problem-solving, and decision-making. You will also learn how to connect and collaborate effectively within leadership settings; helping you establish strong networks and expand your professional opportunities. Whether you're looking to make your voice heard in your community or advance your career, Focus on Leadership equips you with the essential tools to build a powerful leadership presence.This program is open to all women who are interested in pursuing leadership opportunities and making meaningful contributions to their communities. We believe in fostering diversity in leadership and providing access to opportunities that will help you thrive.Who Should JoinAbout the FacilitatorAbiha Syed Abiha Syed, the facilitator for this program, brings over 15 years of experience in community engagement and leadership. As the Community Engagement Coordinator at Immigration Partnership and a co-founder and past Chair of Muslim Women of Cambridge, Abiha has a deep understanding of the importance of inclusive leadership and community-driven change.Abiha’s passion for building relationships, bridging gaps, and empowering women from diverse backgrounds has been the driving force behind her involvement in various community initiatives. She has dedicated her career to fostering equity, diversity, and inclusion in the Waterloo Region, using her platform to amplify marginalized voices and advocate for positive change.In 2017, Abiha co-founded Muslim Women of Cambridge with a mission to support and empower Muslim women in the community. Under her leadership, the organization has made significant strides in promoting inclusivity and respect for diversity. Abiha’s focus on allyship and her commitment to empowering women from all walks of life makes her an ideal facilitator for this program.Abiha believes in creating spaces where diverse voices are heard and valued, and she is passionate about helping women become the leaders they were always meant to be. Through her work, she has inspired countless women to take charge of their futures and pursue leadership opportunities that can change their lives and their communities for the better.Why This Program MattersAt Focus for Ethnic Women (FEW), we are dedicated to empowering racialized women and providing the resources and support needed to help them succeed. As an organization, our mission is to create opportunities for women to develop skills, connect with others, and achieve their full potential. We believe that diverse leadership is essential for creating stronger, more inclusive communities, and this program aligns with our commitment to fostering equity and inclusion across all sectors.By offering Focus on Leadership, we aim to equip women with the skills and confidence to take on leadership roles within nonprofits and beyond. This program is part of our ongoing effort to build a more equitable society, where women from all backgrounds can lead, innovate, and inspire.If you're ready to develop your leadership skills, expand your network, and make a real difference in your community, Focus on Leadership is the program for you. Take the first step towards becoming a powerful, impactful leader in your community. Together, we can create positive change and build a brighter future for all.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. eventName: Nobel Laureates in Conversation: Debunking myths about GMOs with Nobel Laureate Sir Richard Roberts
description: Join the University of Waterloo for an enlightening conversation between two Nobel Laureates as they discuss the important role scientists can play in debunking misinformation.Are genetically modified foods dangerous? GMO stands for Genetically Modified Organism and has been the subject of much debate and misinformation. Nobel Laureate Sir Richard Roberts sits down with Nobel Laureate Donna Strickland to debunk the myths surrounding GMOs and explain why we should not only trust but embrace them. Sir Roberts is a molecular biologist who received the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1993 for discoveries of split genes.This free community lecture is part of a series launched by the Trust in Research Undertaken in Science and Technology (TRuST) scholarly network at the University of Waterloo.Date: Tuesday, January 28, 2025Time: Doors - 6:30 p.m.           Lecture - 7:00 p.m.           Post-lecture reception - 8:30 p.m.Location: University of Waterloo - Federation Hall - 200 University Ave W., Waterloo, ONIf you are unable to join in-person, you can watch through our livestream.Registration on Ticketfi.

October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. Through our collaboration with Cambridge Public Library, together we are working to foster a smooth transition into the Cambridge community.The Library Settlement Partnership program is a partnership of Cambridge Public Library, the YMCA’s Immigrant Services Program, and Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC).Services Offered·  Virtual settlement support to newcomers·  Information sessions relevant to newcomer needs in collaboration with Cambridge Public Library·  LSP staff provide orientation to library services and referrals·  Services available virtually, over the phone, and in-person on select daysContact InformationTuba Sengul (she/her)Languages spoken: Turkish, English, and AzerbaijaniPhone: 519-504-3288Email: tuba.sengul@ytr.ymca.caPlease book an appointment with Tuba before your visit.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. Transforming mental health care in Canada, one community at a time.Learn more about our services and initiatives, and find out how you can contribute to a healthier, supportive Ontario.About our PartnerWounds 2 Wings Trauma and Embodiment Association of Ontario (TEAO) is committed to creating an inclusive, supportive environment for mental health and trauma recovery. Our mission is to provide immediate, community-based mental health services, offering mental health assessments, crisis support, and connection to vital resources. TEAO advocates for a shift in mental health services towards early intervention, especially for vulnerable populations, with the goal of preventing hospitalizations and reducing emergency services. Our team works to deconstruct power dynamics, destigmatize mental health, and promote healing through embodiment practices. Together, we aim to build a resilient community where individuals thrive and support each other toward long-term wellness.By engaging the community, TEAO strives to make mental health care accessible, compassionate, and stigma-free.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

location.name: Old Post Office - Third Floor Classroom IdeaExchange

description:
Empowering women to become tomorrow’s leaders by building skills in board governance, networking, and community-driven decision making for lasting impact.Through this comprehensive training, participants will learn how to navigate the responsibilities of being a nonprofit board member. We focus on practical, hands-on skills including team building, problem-solving, and decision-making. You will also learn how to connect and collaborate effectively within leadership settings; helping you establish strong networks and expand your professional opportunities. Whether you're looking to make your voice heard in your community or advance your career, Focus on Leadership equips you with the essential tools to build a powerful leadership presence.This program is open to all women who are interested in pursuing leadership opportunities and making meaningful contributions to their communities. We believe in fostering diversity in leadership and providing access to opportunities that will help you thrive.Who Should JoinAbout the FacilitatorAbiha Syed Abiha Syed, the facilitator for this program, brings over 15 years of experience in community engagement and leadership. As the Community Engagement Coordinator at Immigration Partnership and a co-founder and past Chair of Muslim Women of Cambridge, Abiha has a deep understanding of the importance of inclusive leadership and community-driven change.Abiha’s passion for building relationships, bridging gaps, and empowering women from diverse backgrounds has been the driving force behind her involvement in various community initiatives. She has dedicated her career to fostering equity, diversity, and inclusion in the Waterloo Region, using her platform to amplify marginalized voices and advocate for positive change.In 2017, Abiha co-founded Muslim Women of Cambridge with a mission to support and empower Muslim women in the community. Under her leadership, the organization has made significant strides in promoting inclusivity and respect for diversity. Abiha’s focus on allyship and her commitment to empowering women from all walks of life makes her an ideal facilitator for this program.Abiha believes in creating spaces where diverse voices are heard and valued, and she is passionate about helping women become the leaders they were always meant to be. Through her work, she has inspired countless women to take charge of their futures and pursue leadership opportunities that can change their lives and their communities for the better.Why This Program MattersAt Focus for Ethnic Women (FEW), we are dedicated to empowering racialized women and providing the resources and support needed to help them succeed. As an organization, our mission is to create opportunities for women to develop skills, connect with others, and achieve their full potential. We believe that diverse leadership is essential for creating stronger, more inclusive communities, and this program aligns with our commitment to fostering equity and inclusion across all sectors.By offering Focus on Leadership, we aim to equip women with the skills and confidence to take on leadership roles within nonprofits and beyond. This program is part of our ongoing effort to build a more equitable society, where women from all backgrounds can lead, innovate, and inspire.If you're ready to develop your leadership skills, expand your network, and make a real difference in your community, Focus on Leadership is the program for you. Take the first step towards becoming a powerful, impactful leader in your community. Together, we can create positive change and build a brighter future for all.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

location.name: Old Post Office - Reading Room IdeaExchange

description:
Rebuilding connections through collective care: TEAO Canada's trauma-informed circles blend somatic practices, psycho-education, and breathwork for healing.Group processing may be an area deserving of more time in communities, organically through conversations, breathwork and movement, which is how Trauma Informed Care Circle (TEAO) has begun to address trauma care and trauma health in communities.These circles will incorporate psycho-education, somatic health, and breathwork to get participants in their somatic bodies to begin to process trauma. We are coming together in somatic movement during the group processing circle so that debriefing, trauma care, and systemic care can be processed.About our PartnerTEAO Canada will hold space for participants, led by Nicole Brown Faulknor — as both a trauma consultant/facilitator and registered psychotherapist. Nicole will explore somatic practices as well, as a way to support rebuilding a relationship with our bodies through collective grief, workspace conflict, and institutional helplessness as a place to be heard (loved) in/from places of systems and hierarchical powerlessness and why your emotional health is our mental health.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. description: BEYONSEA AND THE MOTHERS, world premiere theatrical production, By Teneile Warren.Beyonsea and the Mothers by Teneile Warren is coming to the Conrad Centre for the Performing Arts! 🥭 3 Jamaicans, 1 chance for a second life, and the raw, beautiful tensions between motherhood, identity, and belonging. Join us Jan 29-Feb 9 for a powerful, deeply human story about finding where youtruly belong. 🎭Tickets are on sale now — don’t miss it! 👉 greenlight-arts.comA young girl named Beyonsea is sent to North America to join the mother she only knows through phone calls and remittances. Simone, Beyonsea’s mother, is busy working two jobs. Michael, their neighbour who fled a Jamaican community, befriends Beyonsea and introduces her to his alt persona, Melody Knowles. Three Jamaicans are brought together by circumstance in a place meant to give them second chances.This play discusses queerness, blackness, being an immigrant, and features strained family relationships. Recommended for Ages 12+ years.Thursday, January 30, 2025 | 7:00 PM (Opening Night)Friday, January 31, 2025 | 7:00 PMSaturday, February 1, 2025 | 7:00 PMSunday, February 2, 2025 | 4:00 PM (pay-what-you-can)Wednesday, February 5, 2025 | 7:00 PMThursday, February 6, 2025 | 7:00 PMFriday, February 7, 2025 | 7:00 PMSaturday, February 8, 2025 | 7:00 PMSunday, February 9, 2025 | 4:00 PM (pay-what-you-can)Conrad Centre is an accessible venue. Support persons will receive a complimentary ticket. Please contact Steven Jackson (steven@greenlight-arts.com) to coordinate any specific accessibility needs for your visit.MAILING LIST: https://tinyurl.com/396pjv7s36 King street west, Kitchener ON. BEYONSEA AND THE MOTHERS, world premiere theatrical production, By Teneile Warren.Beyonsea and the Mothers by Teneile Warren is coming to the Conrad Centre for the Performing Arts! 🥭 3 Jamaicans, 1 chance for a second life, and the raw, beautiful tensions between motherhood, identity, and belonging. Join us Jan 29-Feb 9 for a powerful, deeply human story about finding where youtruly belong. 🎭Tickets are on sale now — don’t miss it! 👉 greenlight-arts.comA young girl named Beyonsea is sent to North America to join the mother she only knows through phone calls and remittances. Simone, Beyonsea’s mother, is busy working two jobs. Michael, their neighbour who fled a Jamaican community, befriends Beyonsea and introduces her to his alt persona, Melody Knowles. Three Jamaicans are brought together by circumstance in a place meant to give them second chances.This play discusses queerness, blackness, being an immigrant, and features strained family relationships. Recommended for Ages 12+ years.Thursday, January 30, 2025 | 7:00 PM (Opening Night)Friday, January 31, 2025 | 7:00 PMSaturday, February 1, 2025 | 7:00 PMSunday, February 2, 2025 | 4:00 PM (pay-what-you-can)Wednesday, February 5, 2025 | 7:00 PMThursday, February 6, 2025 | 7:00 PMFriday, February 7, 2025 | 7:00 PMSaturday, February 8, 2025 | 7:00 PMSunday, February 9, 2025 | 4:00 PM (pay-what-you-can)Conrad Centre is an accessible venue. Support persons will receive a complimentary ticket. Please contact Steven Jackson (steven@greenlight-arts.com) to coordinate any specific accessibility needs for your visit.MAILING LIST: https://tinyurl.com/396pjv7s36 King street west, Kitchener ON. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. Through our collaboration with Cambridge Public Library, together we are working to foster a smooth transition into the Cambridge community.The Library Settlement Partnership program is a partnership of Cambridge Public Library, the YMCA’s Immigrant Services Program, and Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC).Services Offered·  Virtual settlement support to newcomers·  Information sessions relevant to newcomer needs in collaboration with Cambridge Public Library·  LSP staff provide orientation to library services and referrals·  Services available virtually, over the phone, and in-person on select daysContact InformationTuba Sengul (she/her)Languages spoken: Turkish, English, and AzerbaijaniPhone: 519-504-3288Email: tuba.sengul@ytr.ymca.caPlease book an appointment with Tuba before your visit.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. Learn about common types of scams, red flags to watch out for, how to protect yourself, and resources for staying safe online.Our Brain Connect program supports The Brain Injury Association of Waterloo-Wellington (BIAWW). Survivors as well as older adults will learn to utilize technology and increase their digital literacy and awareness about online safety. Familiarizing individuals about common types of phishing scams and how to protect their personal information will build confidence and empower them to utilize assistive technologies to improve their daily lives.About our GuestBIAWW is a charitable organization devoted to providing advocacy, education, connections, and empowerment for individuals with acquired brain injury and their families in the ​Waterloo-Wellington region.About Connections 50+As part of our Connections 50+ suite of programming, this older adult-focused program features a variety of entertaining activities such as local musicians, guest speakers, art activities, and much more.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. eventName: Valentine's Day "Death By Chocolate" Tea by The Grand
description: McDougall Cottage’s mouth-watering “Death by Chocolate” Tea by the Grand makes its return, just in time for Valentine’s Day!Grab a special someone, or two, and head down to McDougall Cottage for an indulgent tea experience featuring one of the most beloved flavours of all time, chocolate.We’ll be serving decadent chocolate treats and drinks, alongside a couple of McDougall's ever-popular tea classics, like cucumber and cream-cheese sandwiches, and bottomless tea, of course.If you and your valentine or pal-entine have a sweet tooth, this event is for you!Reserve your spot today—because when it comes to chocolate, too much is never enough!Note: Tickets are also available for in-person purchase at the Cottage during McDougall Cottage's hours of operation.Register NowPlease note:Reservations are required and space is limited, so reserve your spot now!Museum members receive a 10% discount.Tickets are non-refundable.

description: McDougall Cottage’s mouth-watering “Death by Chocolate” Tea by the Grand makes its return, just in time for Valentine’s Day!Grab a special someone, or two, and head down to McDougall Cottage for an indulgent tea experience featuring one of the most beloved flavours of all time, chocolate.We’ll be serving decadent chocolate treats and drinks, alongside a couple of McDougall's ever-popular tea classics, like cucumber and cream-cheese sandwiches, and bottomless tea, of course.If you and your valentine or pal-entine have a sweet tooth, this event is for you!Reserve your spot today—because when it comes to chocolate, too much is never enough!Note: Tickets are also available for in-person purchase at the Cottage during McDougall Cottage's hours of operation.Register NowPlease note:Reservations are required and space is limited, so reserve your spot now!Museum members receive a 10% discount.Tickets are non-refundable.

eventName: What the Health!? A Health Information Fair
description: Explore community health resources for everyone. Get your blood pressure checked. Learn about support groups, recreational opportunities, and special programs for people of all ages. Visit the exhibit Beyond the Bricks: 100 Years of Compassionate Care at St. Mary's General Hospital.

This year treat your valentine to a savory, heart-shaped bread. Dive into our hands-on bread making workshop. Made with fresh yeast and delicious cheeses (and optional bacon), this bread is sure to tantalize your true loves taste buds. Bread will be baked in the Schneider Haus historic wood-fired oven for a one-of-a-kind baking experience!This workshop is for ages 16 and up. Pre-registration required, no refunds.Register Here

Transforming mental health care in Canada, one community at a time.Learn more about our services and initiatives, and find out how you can contribute to a healthier, supportive Ontario.About our PartnerWounds 2 Wings Trauma and Embodiment Association of Ontario (TEAO) is committed to creating an inclusive, supportive environment for mental health and trauma recovery. Our mission is to provide immediate, community-based mental health services, offering mental health assessments, crisis support, and connection to vital resources. TEAO advocates for a shift in mental health services towards early intervention, especially for vulnerable populations, with the goal of preventing hospitalizations and reducing emergency services. Our team works to deconstruct power dynamics, destigmatize mental health, and promote healing through embodiment practices. Together, we aim to build a resilient community where individuals thrive and support each other toward long-term wellness.By engaging the community, TEAO strives to make mental health care accessible, compassionate, and stigma-free.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. description: BEYONSEA AND THE MOTHERS, world premiere theatrical production, By Teneile Warren.Beyonsea and the Mothers by Teneile Warren is coming to the Conrad Centre for the Performing Arts! 🥭 3 Jamaicans, 1 chance for a second life, and the raw, beautiful tensions between motherhood, identity, and belonging. Join us Jan 29-Feb 9 for a powerful, deeply human story about finding where youtruly belong. 🎭Tickets are on sale now — don’t miss it! 👉 greenlight-arts.comA young girl named Beyonsea is sent to North America to join the mother she only knows through phone calls and remittances. Simone, Beyonsea’s mother, is busy working two jobs. Michael, their neighbour who fled a Jamaican community, befriends Beyonsea and introduces her to his alt persona, Melody Knowles. Three Jamaicans are brought together by circumstance in a place meant to give them second chances.This play discusses queerness, blackness, being an immigrant, and features strained family relationships. Recommended for Ages 12+ years.Thursday, January 30, 2025 | 7:00 PM (Opening Night)Friday, January 31, 2025 | 7:00 PMSaturday, February 1, 2025 | 7:00 PMSunday, February 2, 2025 | 4:00 PM (pay-what-you-can)Wednesday, February 5, 2025 | 7:00 PMThursday, February 6, 2025 | 7:00 PMFriday, February 7, 2025 | 7:00 PMSaturday, February 8, 2025 | 7:00 PMSunday, February 9, 2025 | 4:00 PM (pay-what-you-can)Conrad Centre is an accessible venue. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

description:
View an award-winning cinematic feature film presented by the NFB.Directed by Cheryl Foggo2020 | 73 min EnglishJohn Ware Reclaimed follows filmmaker Cheryl Foggo on her quest to re-examine the mythology surrounding John Ware, the Black cowboy who settled in Alberta, Canada, before the turn of the 20th century. Foggo’s research uncovers who this iconic figure might have been, and what his legacy means in terms of anti-Black racism, both past and present.This program is offered as part of the NFB in Libraries program. The film was generously provided for this event by the National Film Board of Canada (NFB).We encourage you to register for this event. location.name: Old Post Office - Third Floor Classroom IdeaExchange

description:
Empowering women to become tomorrow’s leaders by building skills in board governance, networking, and community-driven decision making for lasting impact.Through this comprehensive training, participants will learn how to navigate the responsibilities of being a nonprofit board member. We focus on practical, hands-on skills including team building, problem-solving, and decision-making. You will also learn how to connect and collaborate effectively within leadership settings; helping you establish strong networks and expand your professional opportunities. Whether you're looking to make your voice heard in your community or advance your career, Focus on Leadership equips you with the essential tools to build a powerful leadership presence.This program is open to all women who are interested in pursuing leadership opportunities and making meaningful contributions to their communities. We believe in fostering diversity in leadership and providing access to opportunities that will help you thrive.Who Should JoinAbout the FacilitatorAbiha Syed Abiha Syed, the facilitator for this program, brings over 15 years of experience in community engagement and leadership. As the Community Engagement Coordinator at Immigration Partnership and a co-founder and past Chair of Muslim Women of Cambridge, Abiha has a deep understanding of the importance of inclusive leadership and community-driven change.Abiha’s passion for building relationships, bridging gaps, and empowering women from diverse backgrounds has been the driving force behind her involvement in various community initiatives. She has dedicated her career to fostering equity, diversity, and inclusion in the Waterloo Region, using her platform to amplify marginalized voices and advocate for positive change.In 2017, Abiha co-founded Muslim Women of Cambridge with a mission to support and empower Muslim women in the community. Under her leadership, the organization has made significant strides in promoting inclusivity and respect for diversity. Abiha’s focus on allyship and her commitment to empowering women from all walks of life makes her an ideal facilitator for this program.Abiha believes in creating spaces where diverse voices are heard and valued, and she is passionate about helping women become the leaders they were always meant to be. Through her work, she has inspired countless women to take charge of their futures and pursue leadership opportunities that can change their lives and their communities for the better.Why This Program MattersAt Focus for Ethnic Women (FEW), we are dedicated to empowering racialized women and providing the resources and support needed to help them succeed. As an organization, our mission is to create opportunities for women to develop skills, connect with others, and achieve their full potential. We believe that diverse leadership is essential for creating stronger, more inclusive communities, and this program aligns with our commitment to fostering equity and inclusion across all sectors.By offering Focus on Leadership, we aim to equip women with the skills and confidence to take on leadership roles within nonprofits and beyond. This program is part of our ongoing effort to build a more equitable society, where women from all backgrounds can lead, innovate, and inspire.If you're ready to develop your leadership skills, expand your network, and make a real difference in your community, Focus on Leadership is the program for you. Take the first step towards becoming a powerful, impactful leader in your community. Together, we can create positive change and build a brighter future for all.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. eventName: Sleep Well: Strategies for a Restful Night
description:
Sleep is important to your overall health. Learn tips and tricks to help you get a better night's sleep.This presentation, compiled by the Waterloo Wellington Self-Management Program, provides a comprehensive overview of sleep and its importance for your overall health and well-being. It covers the basics of sleep, including an overview of the circadian rhythm, sleep drive, and the stages of the sleep that happen through the night. We'll also learn about common sleep disruptors and discuss practical tips to help you achieve a better night’s sleep.About the SpeakerDanielle Hughes, RRT, is the program coordinator for the Waterloo Wellington Self-Management Program. With a background in sleep, respiratory care, and health promotion, Danielle is passionate about promoting self-management skills for health and helping others live a well-balanced life. She's also a certified 200-hour yoga teacher and actively teaches classes part time in the Cambridge area.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

description:
As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. Through our collaboration with Cambridge Public Library, together we are working to foster a smooth transition into the Cambridge community.The Library Settlement Partnership program is a partnership of Cambridge Public Library, the YMCA’s Immigrant Services Program, and Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC).Services Offered·  Virtual settlement support to newcomers·  Information sessions relevant to newcomer needs in collaboration with Cambridge Public Library·  LSP staff provide orientation to library services and referrals·  Services available virtually, over the phone, and in-person on select daysContact InformationTuba Sengul (she/her)Languages spoken: Turkish, English, and AzerbaijaniPhone: 519-504-3288Email: tuba.sengul@ytr.ymca.caPlease book an appointment with Tuba before your visit.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. Transforming mental health care in Canada, one community at a time.Learn more about our services and initiatives, and find out how you can contribute to a healthier, supportive Ontario.About our PartnerWounds 2 Wings Trauma and Embodiment Association of Ontario (TEAO) is committed to creating an inclusive, supportive environment for mental health and trauma recovery. Our mission is to provide immediate, community-based mental health services, offering mental health assessments, crisis support, and connection to vital resources. TEAO advocates for a shift in mental health services towards early intervention, especially for vulnerable populations, with the goal of preventing hospitalizations and reducing emergency services. Our team works to deconstruct power dynamics, destigmatize mental health, and promote healing through embodiment practices. Together, we aim to build a resilient community where individuals thrive and support each other toward long-term wellness.By engaging the community, TEAO strives to make mental health care accessible, compassionate, and stigma-free.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. eventName: Family Day Tea by the Grand
description: Start A New Family Day Tradition: Tea by the Grand at McDougall Cottage“Family” is a delightful word because it can mean whatever you want it to mean. Families come in all shapes and sizes and traditional, or not, all are equally wonderful because “Family is what you make it”.On Monday, February 17 McDougall Cottage invites you to gather your loved ones—family by birth or family by choice—for a heartwarming Family Day Tea by the Grand at McDougall Cottage!Indulge in one of our delightful classic teas featuring favourites like cucumber and cream cheese tea sandwiches, ham and cheese pinwheels, buttery scones with preserves and whipped cream, melt-in-your-mouth shortbread and hot chocolate, or bottomless tea.Nestled in the charm of our 165-year-old stone cottage, it’s the perfect setting to sip, savour and share stories with those who matter most and it’s sure to become a tradition for you and those special people you call “Family”.Reserve your spot today—spaces fill up quickly!Register NowPlease note:If you have questions regarding dietary restrictions please contact us before purchase at mcdougall@regionofwaterloo.ca. Gluten-free options are only available at our specialty gluten-free teas. Check our website for upcoming dates or please email us.To assist staff with event set-up: If the members of your party are purchasing tickets individually, rather than under one reservation please email us in advance of the tea, so we can be sure to seat all the members of your party together mcdougall@regionofwaterloo.caChildren under the age of three do not require a ticket, however please let us know if they are attending as it impacts our seating arrangements.Reservations are required and space is limited, so reserve your spot now!Museum Members receive a 10% discount.Tickets are non-refundable.

eventName: Setsubun - sacred offerings to the divine divide
description:
November 30, 2024 - February 23, 2025Curated by Karly BoileauWith a focus on a slow-making process through a Japanese heritage craft practice, Hitoko Okada’s major solo exhibition explores new ceramic and textile works that critically engage with and question the global fashion supply chain as it relates to colonial histories of fast fashion. Her works draw inspiration from geological processes and metabolic evolution of fungi, to apply ancestral knowledge in a present-day context to re-imagine futurisms and ways of being through a queer lens.Explore Setsubun - sacred offerings to the divine divideAccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. Through our collaboration with Cambridge Public Library, together we are working to foster a smooth transition into the Cambridge community.The Library Settlement Partnership program is a partnership of Cambridge Public Library, the YMCA’s Immigrant Services Program, and Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC).Services Offered·  Virtual settlement support to newcomers·  Information sessions relevant to newcomer needs in collaboration with Cambridge Public Library·  LSP staff provide orientation to library services and referrals·  Services available virtually, over the phone, and in-person on select daysContact InformationTuba Sengul (she/her)Languages spoken: Turkish, English, and AzerbaijaniPhone: 519-504-3288Email: tuba.sengul@ytr.ymca.caPlease book an appointment with Tuba before your visit.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. location.name: Old Post Office - Third Floor Classroom IdeaExchange

description:
Empowering women to become tomorrow’s leaders by building skills in board governance, networking, and community-driven decision making for lasting impact.Through this comprehensive training, participants will learn how to navigate the responsibilities of being a nonprofit board member. We focus on practical, hands-on skills including team building, problem-solving, and decision-making. You will also learn how to connect and collaborate effectively within leadership settings; helping you establish strong networks and expand your professional opportunities. Whether you're looking to make your voice heard in your community or advance your career, Focus on Leadership equips you with the essential tools to build a powerful leadership presence.This program is open to all women who are interested in pursuing leadership opportunities and making meaningful contributions to their communities. We believe in fostering diversity in leadership and providing access to opportunities that will help you thrive.Who Should JoinAbout the FacilitatorAbiha Syed Abiha Syed, the facilitator for this program, brings over 15 years of experience in community engagement and leadership. As the Community Engagement Coordinator at Immigration Partnership and a co-founder and past Chair of Muslim Women of Cambridge, Abiha has a deep understanding of the importance of inclusive leadership and community-driven change.Abiha’s passion for building relationships, bridging gaps, and empowering women from diverse backgrounds has been the driving force behind her involvement in various community initiatives. She has dedicated her career to fostering equity, diversity, and inclusion in the Waterloo Region, using her platform to amplify marginalized voices and advocate for positive change.In 2017, Abiha co-founded Muslim Women of Cambridge with a mission to support and empower Muslim women in the community. Under her leadership, the organization has made significant strides in promoting inclusivity and respect for diversity. Abiha’s focus on allyship and her commitment to empowering women from all walks of life makes her an ideal facilitator for this program.Abiha believes in creating spaces where diverse voices are heard and valued, and she is passionate about helping women become the leaders they were always meant to be. Through her work, she has inspired countless women to take charge of their futures and pursue leadership opportunities that can change their lives and their communities for the better.Why This Program MattersAt Focus for Ethnic Women (FEW), we are dedicated to empowering racialized women and providing the resources and support needed to help them succeed. As an organization, our mission is to create opportunities for women to develop skills, connect with others, and achieve their full potential. We believe that diverse leadership is essential for creating stronger, more inclusive communities, and this program aligns with our commitment to fostering equity and inclusion across all sectors.By offering Focus on Leadership, we aim to equip women with the skills and confidence to take on leadership roles within nonprofits and beyond. This program is part of our ongoing effort to build a more equitable society, where women from all backgrounds can lead, innovate, and inspire.If you're ready to develop your leadership skills, expand your network, and make a real difference in your community, Focus on Leadership is the program for you. Take the first step towards becoming a powerful, impactful leader in your community. Together, we can create positive change and build a brighter future for all.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. location.name: Old Post Office - Reading Room IdeaExchange

description:
Rebuilding connections through collective care: TEAO Canada's trauma-informed circles blend somatic practices, psycho-education, and breathwork for healing.Group processing may be an area deserving of more time in communities, organically through conversations, breathwork and movement, which is how Trauma Informed Care Circle (TEAO) has begun to address trauma care and trauma health in communities.These circles will incorporate psycho-education, somatic health, and breathwork to get participants in their somatic bodies to begin to process trauma. We are coming together in somatic movement during the group processing circle so that debriefing, trauma care, and systemic care can be processed.About our PartnerTEAO Canada will hold space for participants, led by Nicole Brown Faulknor — as both a trauma consultant/facilitator and registered psychotherapist. Nicole will explore somatic practices as well, as a way to support rebuilding a relationship with our bodies through collective grief, workspace conflict, and institutional helplessness as a place to be heard (loved) in/from places of systems and hierarchical powerlessness and why your emotional health is our mental health.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. Through our collaboration with Cambridge Public Library, together we are working to foster a smooth transition into the Cambridge community.The Library Settlement Partnership program is a partnership of Cambridge Public Library, the YMCA’s Immigrant Services Program, and Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC).Services Offered·  Virtual settlement support to newcomers·  Information sessions relevant to newcomer needs in collaboration with Cambridge Public Library·  LSP staff provide orientation to library services and referrals·  Services available virtually, over the phone, and in-person on select daysContact InformationTuba Sengul (she/her)Languages spoken: Turkish, English, and AzerbaijaniPhone: 519-504-3288Email: tuba.sengul@ytr.ymca.caPlease book an appointment with Tuba before your visit.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. What is Age Friendly and what would an Age Friendly Cambridge look like?The City of Cambridge is a member of the World Health Organization (WHO) Global Network for Age-friendly Cities and Communities. October 22, 2024 - March 30, 2025Cambridge Art Galleries' inaugural pop-up exhibition at Idea Exchange, Old Post Office, features the work of Guelph-based artist Lauren Wright Vartanian. Her latest work, Stitching Science, merges art and science in 27 intricate diagrammatic embroideries. A culmination of three years of work and countless stitches, these embroideries, each representing a letter of the alphabet, depict scientific concepts in a creative and accessible way. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

Sunday, February 23, 2025:Heath Tarlin in Fizzical FizzicksActivity Code: 54017What do you get when you cross circus skills, science concepts and a couple of wacky characters? You get Fizzical Fizzicks - an interactive, action-packed show about the science of motion! You will be delighted as this dynamic duo performs circus skills like juggling, stilt-walking and unicycling; PLUS dozens of tricks with toys like yo-yos, hula hoops and even a pogo stick. A great combination of physics and circus; its science fun for the whole family! Thanks to the Fundraising efforts of the Cambridge Arts Guild, and sponsor Dryer Realty, tickets are only $5 per person!  Show time: 1:30 pm.  Doors to the Centre open at 1pm.  Depending on the show, performances can be 35 min. or up to 50 min.Tickets only $5 per person.  Purchase your tickets at the Cambridge Centre for the Arts, or online through CORAL.  Activity Code: 54015

description:
Transforming mental health care in Canada, one community at a time.Learn more about our services and initiatives, and find out how you can contribute to a healthier, supportive Ontario.About our PartnerWounds 2 Wings Trauma and Embodiment Association of Ontario (TEAO) is committed to creating an inclusive, supportive environment for mental health and trauma recovery. Our mission is to provide immediate, community-based mental health services, offering mental health assessments, crisis support, and connection to vital resources. TEAO advocates for a shift in mental health services towards early intervention, especially for vulnerable populations, with the goal of preventing hospitalizations and reducing emergency services. Our team works to deconstruct power dynamics, destigmatize mental health, and promote healing through embodiment practices. Together, we aim to build a resilient community where individuals thrive and support each other toward long-term wellness.By engaging the community, TEAO strives to make mental health care accessible, compassionate, and stigma-free.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. description:
As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. Through our collaboration with Cambridge Public Library, together we are working to foster a smooth transition into the Cambridge community.The Library Settlement Partnership program is a partnership of Cambridge Public Library, the YMCA’s Immigrant Services Program, and Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC).Services Offered·  Virtual settlement support to newcomers·  Information sessions relevant to newcomer needs in collaboration with Cambridge Public Library·  LSP staff provide orientation to library services and referrals·  Services available virtually, over the phone, and in-person on select daysContact InformationTuba Sengul (she/her)Languages spoken: Turkish, English, and AzerbaijaniPhone: 519-504-3288Email: tuba.sengul@ytr.ymca.caPlease book an appointment with Tuba before your visit.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. This exhibition coincides with Wright Vartanian’s book release, Stitching Science: Exploring Science from A to Z, published by Firefly Books in the fall of 2024.Lauren Wright Vartanian is a multidisciplinary artist currently focusing on textile art. She has a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Drawing and Painting from OCAD University, where she graduated in 2006. She has been creating and selling art under the name Neurons and Nebulas since 2016. Her work blends art and science in a way that is fun and educational, but also beautiful and inviting. She lives in Guelph with her partner and school aged child.Explore: Stitching ScienceAGE GROUP: |

As a primary settlement agency in Cambridge, YMCA Immigrant Services acts as a “first stop” for newcomers.Through the YMCA Library Settlement Partnerships (LSP), our Settlement Workers are located within the libraries to continue to support newcomer and immigrant needs. Our Settlement Workers can provide support with citizenship, housing, education, English language assessments, connecting with community resources, and much more. Through our collaboration with Cambridge Public Library, together we are working to foster a smooth transition into the Cambridge community.The Library Settlement Partnership program is a partnership of Cambridge Public Library, the YMCA’s Immigrant Services Program, and Immigration, Refugees, and Citizenship Canada (IRCC).Services Offered·  Virtual settlement support to newcomers·  Information sessions relevant to newcomer needs in collaboration with Cambridge Public Library·  LSP staff provide orientation to library services and referrals·  Services available virtually, over the phone, and in-person on select daysContact InformationTuba Sengul (she/her)Languages spoken: Turkish, English, and AzerbaijaniPhone: 519-504-3288Email: tuba.sengul@ytr.ymca.caPlease book an appointment with Tuba before your visit.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized. Empowering women to become tomorrow’s leaders by building skills in board governance, networking, and community-driven decision making for lasting impact.Through this comprehensive training, participants will learn how to navigate the responsibilities of being a nonprofit board member. We focus on practical, hands-on skills including team building, problem-solving, and decision-making. You will also learn how to connect and collaborate effectively within leadership settings; helping you establish strong networks and expand your professional opportunities. Whether you're looking to make your voice heard in your community or advance your career, Focus on Leadership equips you with the essential tools to build a powerful leadership presence.This program is open to all women who are interested in pursuing leadership opportunities and making meaningful contributions to their communities. We believe in fostering diversity in leadership and providing access to opportunities that will help you thrive.Who Should JoinAbout the FacilitatorAbiha Syed Abiha Syed, the facilitator for this program, brings over 15 years of experience in community engagement and leadership. As the Community Engagement Coordinator at Immigration Partnership and a co-founder and past Chair of Muslim Women of Cambridge, Abiha has a deep understanding of the importance of inclusive leadership and community-driven change.Abiha’s passion for building relationships, bridging gaps, and empowering women from diverse backgrounds has been the driving force behind her involvement in various community initiatives. She has dedicated her career to fostering equity, diversity, and inclusion in the Waterloo Region, using her platform to amplify marginalized voices and advocate for positive change.In 2017, Abiha co-founded Muslim Women of Cambridge with a mission to support and empower Muslim women in the community. Under her leadership, the organization has made significant strides in promoting inclusivity and respect for diversity. Abiha’s focus on allyship and her commitment to empowering women from all walks of life makes her an ideal facilitator for this program.Abiha believes in creating spaces where diverse voices are heard and valued, and she is passionate about helping women become the leaders they were always meant to be. Through her work, she has inspired countless women to take charge of their futures and pursue leadership opportunities that can change their lives and their communities for the better.Why This Program MattersAt Focus for Ethnic Women (FEW), we are dedicated to empowering racialized women and providing the resources and support needed to help them succeed. As an organization, our mission is to create opportunities for women to develop skills, connect with others, and achieve their full potential. We believe that diverse leadership is essential for creating stronger, more inclusive communities, and this program aligns with our commitment to fostering equity and inclusion across all sectors.By offering Focus on Leadership, we aim to equip women with the skills and confidence to take on leadership roles within nonprofits and beyond. This program is part of our ongoing effort to build a more equitable society, where women from all backgrounds can lead, innovate, and inspire.If you're ready to develop your leadership skills, expand your network, and make a real difference in your community, Focus on Leadership is the program for you. Take the first step towards becoming a powerful, impactful leader in your community. Together, we can create positive change and build a brighter future for all.AccessibilityIf you require an accessibility accommodation for this program or event, please tell us how we can meet your needs as soon as possible so arrangements can be organized.
